title: Multi-context principal component analysis
summary: Multi-context Principal Component Analysis (MCPCA) is a novel theoretical and algorithmic framework that generalizes PCA to systematically identify underlying factors explaining variation across *subsets* of contexts. Applied to gene expression data, MCPCA reveals shared axes of variation among cancer types and uncovers a specific axis whose variability (not mean) in tumor cells is associated with lung cancer progression, insights not achievable by traditional PCA methods. This framework offers a principled way to understand complex biological data across heterogeneous conditions.

title: Tracing 3D Anatomy in 2D Strokes: A Multi-Stage Projection Driven Approach to Cervical Spine Fracture Identification
summary: This study introduces a multi-stage, projection-driven deep learning pipeline for automated cervical spine fracture identification from 3D CT volumes. It leverages optimized 2D axial, sagittal, and coronal projections for efficient localization and segmentation of vertebrae (C1-C7), followed by an ensemble of 2.5D models for fracture detection, achieving high accuracy comparable to expert radiologists while reducing computational complexity.

title: A Computer Vision Hybrid Approach: CNN and Transformer Models for Accurate Alzheimer's Detection from Brain MRI Scans
summary: This study introduces Evan_V2, a novel hybrid deep learning model combining CNN and Transformer architectures through feature-level fusion, for the accurate four-class classification of Alzheimer's disease (AD) from brain MRI scans. Achieving an exceptional 99.99% accuracy and superior F1-score and ROC AUC, Evan_V2 significantly outperforms individual CNN and Transformer models, highlighting the potential of ensemble strategies for highly reliable AD diagnosis.

title: A comprehensive overview of deep learning models for object detection from videos/images
summary: This comprehensive review synthesizes modern deep learning techniques for object detection in video and image surveillance, categorizing methods by core architectures, data processing, and addressing challenges like dynamic environments and real-time needs. It evaluates the current effectiveness of semantic object detection, focusing on CNN-based, GAN-assisted, and temporal fusion approaches, which hold significant potential for advanced medical image and video analysis by enhancing robustness and accuracy.

title: Dosimetry for Proton Therapy Using a β-Ga$_2$O$_3$ Metal-Semiconductor-Metal Detector with Low-Noise Amplification
summary: This paper evaluates a novel β-Ga$_2$O$_3$ metal-semiconductor-metal (MSM) detector combined with low-noise amplification for dosimetry in intensity-modulated proton therapy (IMPT). The study demonstrates the detector's linear response to proton dose and its accurate tracking of varying proton energies, matching established ionization chamber data and simulated distributions, positioning it as a promising advancement for validating complex IMPT treatment plans.

title: Efficient Imputation for Patch-based Missing Single-cell Data via Cluster-regularized Optimal Transport
summary: CROT is an optimal transport-based imputation algorithm designed to efficiently handle large, patch-based missing data in single-cell sequencing datasets. It effectively captures underlying data structures, demonstrating superior imputation accuracy and significantly reduced runtime, making it scalable for large-scale, heterogeneous, and high-dimensional datasets. This robust solution addresses critical challenges in both biological and clinical data analysis.
